Award.AwardTitle: Modeling, Computational and Inferential Issues in Fingerprint and Health Monitoring Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex data structures with intrinsic multivariate and multilevel characteristics arise frequently in various scientific disciplines. This proposal discusses two such application domains, namely, the areas of health monitoring and fingerprint based authentication. The scientific questions posed are usually associated with high-dimensional parameter spaces, such as spaces of point patterns and functions, and are addressed in a conceptually unified and meaningful way with the development of novel hierarchical models on general object spaces. These hierarchical models are flexible and adept at capturing salient data characteristics, such as clustering and spatial dependence, whose forms vary from one application to another. The proposal develops statistical methodology utilizing parametric multivariate generalized linear mixed models and non-parametric Dirichlet process priors, extended to the space of objects, for studying attributes and the effect of covariates encountered in fingerprint and socio-economic-health applications. Due to the high-dimensionality of the intrinsic spaces, several innovative procedures are developed to overcome ensuing computational challenges in the Bayesian framework, including theoretically justified approximations to the likelihood and predictive inference. An added feature of these inferential tools is to extend posterior analysis of quantities such as means, variances and credible sets, in a meaningful way to the space of objects.

The scientific goals addressed in this proposal will benefit research in public and social health, engineering and legal forensics. The impact on societal and demographic policy making, for example, will be in the discovery of socio-demographic regions with extreme health and economic conditions, the identification of their potential causes and in the decisions made to mobilize resources accordingly. The proposed research has impact on how forensic evidence should be reported as well. Many forensic scientists as well as legal scholars have become increasingly aware of the shortcomings of fingerprint evidence as is presented in a court of law, and that methodology for assessing the extent of uniqueness of fingerprints requires further scientific validity. Several of these issues are addressed by developing quantitative methods for reporting fingerprint evidence, for example, when additional fingerprint attributes such as quality are available. This research will have broader impact in health and security surveillance, and their monitoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was to study issues in statistical modeling of fingerprint and health monitoring data and develop hierarchical models that capture characteristics of such applications.

 

Our work supported by this grant contributed in several areas of Statistics by proposing new approaches to analyze fingerprint data and health monitoring data. More specifically, we developed hierarchical spatial regression models to incorporate image quality in the analysis of fingerprint image data. Our approach provides improved uncertainty measure for fingerprint matching which can be practically used.

 

Also, we developed curve clustering approach that can capture change-point in addition to clustering. This is useful to detect the changes in cancer rates over time and identify groups of cancer curves which have similar patterns. We extended the approach to spatial clustering. These methods to identify clusters in cancer risk rates over regions can uncover characteristics of cancer risk so that health policy makers can investigate further to understand causes and mechanisms of cancer risk distribution for better decision making.

 

One of our papers on analyzing Florida pediatric cancer rates has received attention from statistics community as well as general public by news release from media.  Several researchers independently analyzed the same data set to identify high risk regions. We applied our spatial clustering model to the data set. Similar findings were obtained from multiple researchers which can bring stronger attention for health policy makers to further investigate those areas.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/13/2015
Modified by: Chae Young Lim

Our approach provides improved uncertainty measure for fingerprint matching which can be practically used. This is useful to detect the changes in cancer rates over time and identify groups of cancer curves which have similar patterns. We extended the approach to spatial clustering. These methods to identify clusters in cancer risk rates over regions can uncover characteristics of cancer risk so that health policy makers can investigate further to understand causes and mechanisms of cancer risk distribution for better decision making. One of our papers on analyzing Florida pediatric cancer rates has received attention from statistics community as well as general public by news release from media. Several researchers independently analyzed the same data set to identify high risk regions. We applied our spatial clustering model to the data set. Similar findings were obtained from multiple researchers which can bring stronger attention for health policy makers to further investigate those areas.
